channel.description: Stay up to date on everything happening in The New Yorker and on newyorker.com.

channel.dc:subject: everything

item.title: Book News: Proust’s First Poem, Travel Apps
item.description: Ann Napolitano visits Flannery O’Connor’s childhood home in Savannah. “Is it too much of a stretch to say that deconstruction was at some level an allegory of personal exclusion?” Emily Eakin on how Derrida’s...
item.dc:creator: Rachel Arons

item.title: Rescuing the Eisenhower Memorial
item.description: The Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial would take up much of a four-acre plot across the street from the National Air and Space Museum, which itself sits on the increasingly cluttered National Mall, and would be dominated by four eighty-foot metal curtains showing scenes from Eisenhower’s life. It has managed to achieve something rare in Washington: in true bipartisan spirit, almost everyone hates it.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Frank

item.title: Passover with the Bronfmans
item.description: Bronfman said that he wrote his version of the Haggadah, the text that guides the Passover meal while telling the story of the Jews’ exodus from Egypt, with children in mind. Illustrated with watercolors by his wife, Jan Aronson, it includes quotations from such goyim as Franklin D. Roosevelt and Ralph Waldo Emerson, and there is no Hebrew in it.
item.dc:creator: John Ortved

item.title: As Syria Bleeds, Lebanon Reels
item.description: Wouldn’t it be ironic if the popular awakening sweeping the Middle East had the unintended effect of undermining the one established Arab democracy? On Friday, Lebanese Prime Minister Najib Mikati resigned. His departure followed...
item.dc:creator: Dexter Filkins

item.title: Cover Story: New Yorkers in Love
item.description: When you look at New Yorkers, you can see some things that simply don’t change. Witness the slideshow below of loving couples in Art Deco New Yorker covers from the nineteen-twenties.
item.dc:creator: Mina Kaneko and Francoise Mouly

item.title: Reconciliation at My Lai
item.description: One day that summer Mike Boehm went to his mother’s attic, where his medals from Vietnam were stored, and threw them in the garbage. He informed the veterans’ affairs office that the G.I. Bill was “blood money” and that he could no longer accept it.
item.dc:creator: Dan Kaufman

item.title: Book News: Willa Cather’s Letters, @DavidGrann
item.description: More than five hundred of Willa Cather’s letters will be published in an anthology next month after decades of tight archival restrictions. “If print could talk, it would surely be telling the world, Mark...
item.dc:creator: Rachel Arons

item.title: Yusef Komunyakaa: “Night Gigging.”
item.description:
A three-pronged spear waits for a bullfrog to sing bass from the weedy millpond.
A silhouette lingers, cleaved from the kneeling man, back to hunger & simple philosophy of the spheres,
how dirt begs for a seed to work into a thick root to pry up the foundation of . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Yusef Komunyakaa

item.title: Vince Aletti: A Bill Brandt retrospective, at MOMA.
item.description: Bill Brandt, the subject of a brilliant retrospective at MOMA, was the photographer who best defined England in the years just before the Second World War. Born in Hamburg and trained in Paris, where he couldn’t resist the heady influence of Man Ray, Atget, and Brassaï, he . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Vince Aletti

item.title: This Week in Fiction: Sarah Braunstein
item.description: In your story, “Marjorie Lemke,” which appears in this week’s issue, we meet a woman who considers herself a loser. Where did things go wrong for Marjorie Lemke?
item.dc:creator: Willing Davidson

item.title: Steve Coll: Why the Administration targeted a C.I.A. officer.
item.description: In 2007, John Kiriakou was settling into a lucrative life as a former spy. His fourteen-year career as a C.I.A. officer had included thrilling, if occasionally hazardous, tours as a specialist in counterterrorism. In Athens, in 1999 and 2000, he recruited several foreign agents to spy for the United . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Steve Coll

item.title: Silvia Killingsworth: Aamanns-Copenhagen in Tribeca review.
item.description: paragraph class="noindent">On Canal Street between Sixth Avenue and the Holland Tunnel lies an odd, triangular pocket park, bound to the southeast by one of the most maddeningly inaccessible stretches of pavement in New York—film buffs will recognize it as the home of Tribeca Cinemas. Now it . . .
item.dc:creator: Silvia Killingsworth

item.title: Sasha Frere-Jones: Has Justin Timberlake stopped growing?
item.description: Justin Timberlake has built a career as a singer and an actor by being genuinely affable. It’s a rarer quality than it seems at first—many television personalities strive for affability but end up looking maniacally suggestible. Timberlake began at age ten, in Millington, Tennessee, singing Al . . .
item.dc:creator: Sasha Frere-Jones

item.title: Sarah Braunstein: “Marjorie Lemke.”
item.description: She was only twenty but had an old person’s name. How she despised her name: its merry singsong, its too many vowels, its very M.L., benign initials that in fourth grade inspired Tommy Sugarman to crow, “Major Loser, Major Loser, Major Loser.” Was she a loser . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Sarah Braunstein

item.title: Russell Platt: New classical albums from Annie Gosfield and Lee Hyla.
item.description: paragraph class="noindent">John Zorn’s Tzadik label has never courted celebrity. Its catalogue consists largely of albums by talented avant-garde composers who don’t naturally seek the limelight, and that’s a welcome philosophy. A great example is Annie Gosfield, whose fourth disk for the . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Russell Platt

item.title: Reeves Wiedeman: How to call a buzzer beater.
item.description: For a television sports broadcaster, nothing can make a career like a late-game call in a big moment. This is especially true in the month of March, during the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, which has become known both for intraoffice gambling and for the frequency with which . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Reeves Wiedeman

item.title: Rebecca Mead: A podiatrist’s guide to wearing heels.
item.description: When Dr. Emily Splichal was growing up in rural North Dakota, footwear loomed small. Then, when she was a senior in high school, she made a trip to New York City to visit an older sister. “Everyone was wearing jeans and heels,” Splichal recalled recently. “That is . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Mead

item.title: Out Loud: Skeptically Yours
item.description: Here, Michael Schulman listens to and explains a few of the songs that made Time Minchin famous in his native Australia and in the U.K. Also, a phone call with Minchin himself.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Michael Schulman: An Australian comic translates Roald Dahl’s “Matilda” for Broadway.
item.description: Three years before Roald Dahl died, he was stumped by a five-year-old. Like many of his protagonists, Matilda Wormwood was a precocious youngster surrounded by monstrous adults and grotesque peers. But in early drafts of “Matilda,” Dahl had painted her as a wicked child who uses . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Michael Schulman

item.title: Louise Gluck: “An Adventure.”
item.description: 1. It came to me one night as I was falling asleep that I had finished with those amorous adventures to which I had long been a slave. Finished with love? my heart murmured. To which I responded that many profound discoveries awaited us, hoping, at the same time, I . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Louise Glück

item.title: Judith Thurman: The desires of Margaret Fuller.
item.description: In May of 1850, after four years abroad, Margaret Fuller set sail from Livorno to New York, bound for her native Massachusetts. She was just about to turn forty, and her stature in America was unique. In the space of a decade, she had invented a new vocation: the female . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Judith Thurman

item.title: Jeffrey Toobin: Gay marriage at the Supreme Court.
item.description: In 2003, the Supreme Court decided that gay people could no longer be thrown in prison for having consensual sex. Specifically, Justice Anthony Kennedy’s opinion, in Lawrence v. Texas, declared that Texas’s anti-sodomy law “demeans the lives of homosexual persons” and violated the . . .
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Toobin

item.title: Hilton Als: Richard Greenberg’s “Breakfast at Tiffany’s.”
item.description: Truman Capote’s “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” is so extraordinary a work that it incites not writerly envy but pride. Published in 1958, it’s one of those pop masterpieces—like Tom Wolfe’s “Radical Chic” and Gore Vidal’s . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Hilton Als

item.title: Hilton Als: Guillermo Calderon’s “Neva,” at the Public.
item.description: At the end of Guillermo Calderón’s strange, new, and vital “Neva” (at the Public, through March 31), the forty-two-year-old author and director—who grew up in Chile during Pinochet’s regime—lets it rip and shows us his . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Hilton Als

item.title: Goings on About Town: The Theatre
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPENINGS AND PREVIEWS<!--/goatcategory--> Please call the phone number listed with the theatre for timetables and ticket information.
<!--goatTitle-->THE ASSEMBLED PARTIES<!--/goatTitle--> Lynne Meadow directs this play by Richard Greenberg (“Take Me Out”), for Manhattan Theatre Club, about a Jewish family living on the Upper . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Readings and Talks
item.description: goatTitle-->STRAND BOOK STORE<!--/goatTitle--> Three spring readings here celebrate the tenth anniversary of the Poetry Society of America’s Chapbook Fellowship. The first features Dan Chelotti and Yusef Komunyakaa, who will read and discuss their work. Alice Quinn, the executive director of the Society, will introduce the poets . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: On the Horizon
item.description: MOVIES THE EYE IN AFRICA April 3-9 This year’s edition of the New York African Film Festival, which will be held at Film Society of Lincoln Center, pays tribute to the late Senegalese director Ousmane Sembène—the first internationally acclaimed African director. The program includes . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Night Life
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->ROCK AND POP<!--/goatcategory--> Musicians and night-club proprietors live complicated lives; it’s advisable to check in advance to confirm engagements.
<!--goatTitle-->APUTUMPU FESTIVAL<!--/goatTitle--> This small weekend gathering, now in its second year, brings more than two dozen local up-and-comers to a handful . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Movies
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPENING<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->BLANCANIEVES<!--/goatTitle--> A version of “Snow White” set in nineteen-twenties Spain. Directed by Pablo Berger; starring Maribel Verdú and Daniel Giménez Cacho. In Spanish. Opening March 29. (In limited release.)
<!--goatTitle-->FAMILY WEEKEND<!--/goatTitle--> A comic drama, about a . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Dance
item.description: goatTitle-->ABT STUDIO COMPANY/ROYAL BALLET SCHOOL<!--/goatTitle--> Two élite training programs join forces for a performance at the Ailey Citigroup Theatre. Comparisons are inevitable: the British dancers tend to be very neat, modest, and quietly poised. The Americans tend to be more boisterous, if a bit rougher around . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Classical Music
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPERA<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->METROPOLITAN OPERA<!--/goatTitle--> March 27 at 7:30 and March 30 at 8: The tenor José Cura is reportedly causing a stir in the title role of Verdi’s “Otello”—not so surprising, since it’s the calling card worldwide . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Art
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->MUSEUMS AND LIBRARIES<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->METROPOLITAN MUSEUM<!--/goatTitle--> Fifth Ave. at 82nd St. (212-535-7710)—“Impressionism, Fashion, and Modernity.” Through May 27. | “African Art, New York, and the Avant-Garde.” Through Sept. 2. | “The Path of Nature: French Paintings from the Wheelock Whitney . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Above and Beyond
item.description: goatTitle-->“RUNNING LATE WITH SCOTT ROGOWSKY”<!--/goatTitle--> This biweekly live talk show features guests from the worlds of media and entertainment. Rogowsky, a young comedian, has been hosting these shows around town for about eighteen months, and he has managed to secure the likes of Chris Elliott, Rachel . . .

item.title: Gavin Shulman: “Taxicab Conversation.”
item.description: The important call that every New York City cabdriver is on: a translation. DRIVER: Hello. CALLER: Hello. What is up? DRIVER: Not much. I am driving. CALLER: Again? DRIVER: Yes. Yes. I am driving. CALLER: You are always driving when we talk. DRIVER: I am a driver. I drive a . . .
item.dc:creator: Gavin Shulman

item.title: David Sedaris: A journey made more difficult.
item.description: There are plenty of things I take for granted, but not being burglarized was never one of them. Whether I was in a good neighborhood or a crummy one, in a house or an apartment or a hotel room, every time I walked in and found my dresser drawers not . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: David Sedaris

item.title: David Denby: A screening of Stanley Kubrick’s “The Shining,” at IFC Center.
item.description: In Stanley Kubrick’s “The Shining” (at IFC Center March 28), a blocked writer, Jack (Jack Nicholson), works as the caretaker of a huge, empty Colorado resort, accompanied by his simpleminded wife, Wendy (Shelley Duvall), and their young son, Danny (Danny Lloyd), who can see the hotel . . .
item.dc:creator: David Denby

item.title: David Denby: “The Place Beyond the Pines,” “Olympus Has Fallen” reviews.
item.description: Derek Cianfrance’s earnest, broodingly ambitious movie “The Place Beyond the Pines” begins with a close-up of Ryan Gosling’s tattooed torso, which, as Emma Stone noted, in “Crazy Stupid Love,” looks Photoshopped for perfection. The shot continues, without a cut, as Gosling . . .
item.dc:creator: David Denby

item.title: Books: Simon Armitage’s “Walking Home” review.
item.description: In the summer of 2010, Armitage, a British poet, set out to walk the Pennine Way, a mountainous trail, some two hundred and sixty miles long, that runs from the Scottish Borders to the English Midlands, passing through the author’s home town, in Yorkshire. Part pilgrimage and part . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: Ron Currie, Jr.’s “Flimsy Little Plastic Miracles” review.
item.description: This novel-as-memoir quotes the last line of the author’s first novel (“the one nobody read”): “ ‘Anything, anything, anything is possible.’ ” Anything does seem possible in Currie’s fantastical fiction: a man knows exactly how and when the world will . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: Ray Fisman and Tim Sullivan’s “The Org” review.
item.description: Office life is notoriously spotted with inefficiency and indignity, yet, as the authors of this appealing study in popular economics argue, corporations and the people who work for them have many incentives to put up with it. The most obvious reason, as demonstrated by examples from such familiar innovators as . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: A. L. Kennedy’s “The Blue Book” review.
item.description: Kennedy’s sixth novel has the makings of a farce. Through some complicated mismanagement, Elizabeth Barber finds herself on a weeklong cruise with both Derek, her “soon-to-be-ex-almost-future-husband,” and Arthur, her on-off lover. She and Arthur used to work together as . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Alec Wilkinson: The Hip Hop Word Count.
item.description: Here’s the origin story for Hip Hop Word Count, the database of fifty thousand rap songs, beginning in 1979, which, among other things, can tell someone when a particular word, such as “champagne,” first appeared in a rap song, whose song it was, and where he . . .
item.dc:creator: Alec Wilkinson

item.title: Adam Gopnik: A lesson in sauce bearnaise.
item.description: One of the things that anyone who has ever taken a hand to sauce-making wants to watch is someone who really knows how to make a sauce béarnaise, the classic French sauce of butter and white wine and tarragon and eggs. It is the perfect embodiment of . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Adam Gopnik

item.title: The Crisis in a Nutshell: Quotes of the Week
item.description: “Eventually people will realize even though you go to Harvard you can still hoop.”—Houston Rockets point guard Jeremy Lin.
item.dc:creator: Aswini Periyasamy

item.title: Peace Comes to Turkey
item.description: On Thursday afternoon, in front of a crowd so large it surged over fences and up scaffolding, peace was declared in Turkey. A letter from Abdullah Ocalan had been carried from the island prison where he is being held to Newroz Park on the outskirts of Diyarbakir, where it was read—first in Kurdish and then in Turkish.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Krajeski

item.title: Charles Krafft and the Conundrum of Nazi Art
item.description: Last month, an article by Jen Graves in Seattle’s weekly paper The Stranger exposed the artist Charles Krafft as a white nationalist and Holocaust denier, and former admirers of his work are now stripping it from their walls. Should they?
item.dc:creator: Rachel Arons

item.title: Backblogged: Our Five Favorite Sentences of the Week
item.description: There is something deeply harmful in all of the adults reinforcing the idea that the lives of teen-age boys are destroyed when a girl says what they have done.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: What’s Standing in the Way of Gay Marriage?
item.description: It is possible that a procedural rule, misunderstood even by lawyers, could derail the gay-marriage cases before the Supreme Court. Standing essentially requires that the party asking the court to do something has, in some legally cognizable way, been injured by the decision it’s appealing.
item.dc:creator: Richard Socarides

item.title: Weekend Reading: Tycoons’ Apartments, California Farm Laborors, Mali’s Struggles
item.description: The most memorable magazine article I read this week was Nicholas Shaxson’s investigation, from the April issue of Vanity Fair, of London’s One Hyde Park, where flats sell for up to two hundred and fourteen million dollars.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Fromson

item.title: Political Scene: Obama’s Middle East Entanglements
item.description: David Remnick and Ryan Lizza talk with the Dorothy Wickenden about the President’s visit and what—if anything—it might portend for America’s involvement in the Middle East’s most pressing issues: the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the war in Syria, and the Iranian nuclear threat.
item.dc:creator: Matthew McKnight
